body: @koalie any advice?

@dontcallmedom I concur with @danyork but when I reviewed the document I chose to ignore it for the sake of readability because "Machine Learning-based systems" looks odd, and "Machine-Learning-based systems" is complex. There is just this one occurrence in the document. I suggest to leave as is or flip the words: "systems based on Machine Learning".

could you help qualify more specifically what this isn't a good balance? I imagine two aspects make this less good than the search engines model:
* fewer relevant sources being exposed
* less incentives to visit the sources if the AI system has already provided (what at least looks like) the specific answer

my understanding of C2PA is that it allows to embed signed claims into media files on their sources, including potential ML-based processing; but as far as I understand, it doesn't provide a mechanism that prevents removing these claims, and in particular, wouldn't prevent someone with nefarious intent to present synthetic content as a human creation. Is that correct? this is what I was trying to convey in terms of "no credible solution".

+1 on adding the potential role of UA in surfacing provenance information

Yes, it's both of those things. For any given topic, a search engine is likely to return a larger number of sources. And because of the interactive nature of LLM AI interfaces, users may well prefer to stay there rather than visit the sources, reducing the creator's ability to build its own audience, or for users even to recognise that the value they received in getting an answer is attributable to the original sources.

That topic is (meant to be) covered in [4.1.1 "Transparency on AI-generated content"](https://www.w3.org/reports/ai-web-impact/#transparency-on-ai-generated-content):
> it creates a systemic risk for content consumers in no longer being able to distinguish or discover authoritative or curated content in a sea of credible (but either possibly or wilfully wrong) generated content.

Is there a different angle that you think should be covered in the context of [4.5 "Balancing content creators incentives and consumers rights"](https://www.w3.org/reports/ai-web-impact/#balancing-content-creators-incentives-and-consumers-rights)? or additional description needed on this point in 4.1.1?
It does, and re-reading it I think it's OK as is.
I've filed https://github.com/w3c/ai-web-impact/pull/12 with some proposed related additions
@chrisn does this work?

Yes, claims can be removed, and C2PA is also not a "truth" mechanism, it's a provenance mechanism, so someone can make untrue claims but these are traceable to who made them, and then they take on the associated reputational risk.

I'll think about a proposed wording change ... I think "no credible solution that could guarantee" is maybe too strong as there are solutions that well-intentioned actors can use if they choose to.

I'll also create a PR for the UA aspect.

many thanks @xueyuanjia ! I've made a few changes in the doc to fix errors in ReSpec associated with autolinks to definitions: https://github.com/w3c/ai-web-impact/pull/18/commits/a02055b20a51d100396b4cb4ec5cb271407cbb86 - if you could check that I didn't mess it up, this would be great!

Do you know which version of the document the translation is based on? e.g. what date or commit was it built from?

> I've made a few changes ... [a02055b](https://github.com/w3c/ai-web-impact/commit/a02055b20a51d100396b4cb4ec5cb271407cbb86) 

I made [one edit](https://github.com/w3c/ai-web-impact/pull/18/commits/6ff56080a7b5832674ec76f0e8064558f2be0bb9) .

> 
> Do you know which version of the document the translation is based on? e.g. what date or commit was it built from?

The translation is based on the version firstly [announced on 13 March](https://www.w3.org/blog/2024/managing-the-impact-of-ai-machine-learning-on-the-web/), which should be [this version](https://github.com/w3c/ai-web-impact/tree/c528c37b81c970e631b547499d056741f5a51824). Further commits since 14 March haven't been reflected.
I've made [another change](https://github.com/w3c/ai-web-impact/pull/18/commits/c41b6b9fa59267e7728b33cf265f65f873af388a) to pacify respec - can you take another look?

> I've made [another change](https://github.com/w3c/ai-web-impact/pull/18/commits/c41b6b9fa59267e7728b33cf265f65f873af388a) to pacify respec..

Thank you @dontcallmedom I made [a further edit](https://github.com/w3c/ai-web-impact/pull/18/commits/08a034b74d69124cfbf0f280268589a8111e7431) and the translation still makes perfect sense.

The document links to the ethics in ML document on bias, which itself quotes a definition as "a systematic skew in decision-making that results in unfair outcomes" from  the [CDEI Review into Bias in Algorithmic Decision-Making](https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/938857/Summary_Slide_Deck_-_CDEI_review_into_bias_in_algorithmic_decision-making.pdf).

[A Survey on Bias and Fairness in Machine Learning](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1908.09635.pdf) quotes a definition of fairness as "absence of any prejudice or favoritism toward an individual or group based on their inherent or acquired characteristics".

(this suggests that using a model trained on the general population in the context of a pediatric hospital wouldn't be an illustration of bias - merely a case of using the wrong tool for the job)

Should the document directly quote a definition of bias (rather than just link to it)? should that include a definition of fairness as well (such as the one above)?

There is a similar case proposed by Dr Kate Vredenburgh of LSE when [Google Mistakenly Tags Black People as ‘Gorillas,’ Showing Limits of Algorithms](https://www.wsj.com/articles/BL-DGB-42522). 

If can be useful to say that a bias can be generated also by the  _accuracy_ of the data set if it were interesting to specify
another reference: ISO 22989 has the following definition for bias "systematic difference in treatment of certain objects, people or groups in comparison to others"
"unfair outcomes" seems to move the definition problem to asking what's fair. The ISO definition is better, IMHO.

Please see https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/230538.230561 Friedman, B., Nissenbaum, H. (1996) Bias in Computing Systems,. ACM Transactions on Information Systems, 14(3), 330 –347, ACM 1046-8188/96/0700 –0330 for a fuller understanding of technical and computational bias.

That paper uses "Accordingly, we use the term bias to refer to computer systems that systematically and unfairly discriminate against certain individuals or groups of individuals in favor of others."

However, their initial example is of a biased airline reservation system which effectively preferred US domestic carriers, and carriers aren't individuals…

And again we hit the question of what's 'unfair'.

I have prepared a pull request adding the ISO definition of bias to the document https://github.com/w3c/ai-web-impact/pull/21 

@dwsinger would this address partially or completely this issue?

[ISO/IEC TR 24027](https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/en/#iso:std:iso-iec:tr:24027:ed-1:v1:en) in section 5 contains a good discussion of how bias relates to fairness in the context of AI systems. Worth a look.
yes, adding a definition would address my direct concern. we can then argue about whether it's right, of course, but that's separate

Hi @iherman,

That's a very good point. From my analysis, AI raises the bar from both a defender's and an attacker's point of view. It is a powerful tool that complicates the fateful cat-and-mouse game.

As you say, to defend sites from anti-automation, there are CAPTCHAs. CAPTCHAs can be resolved by AIs relatively easily, and then the defender perhaps puts other countermeasures in place to protect himself. Also, there is an ongoing discussion in several communities regarding CAPTCHAs' usefulness (and the use, for example, of JavaScript challenges that do not worsen the user's UX). 

Conversely, defenders can use WAFs that use AIs to protect themselves from attacks and not use regexp or visitation behaviors to figure out whether it is a bot (which may also have privacy effects).

Is a particularly interesting and broad topic.

> CAPTCHAs can be resolved by AIs relatively easily

which is all the more ironic because, as far as I know, CAPTCHAS, as far as I know, were originally used (maybe still are) to train AI systems :-)

CAPTCHAs were used to avoid programs, and now they are still used to train programs (AI) using humans for free :)

Reminds me a little bit of:

> It was said that you would destroy the Sith, not join them! Bring balance to the Force, not leave it in darkness!

I think that depends on how the PDS is architected. Some PDSs are basically stores with an ACL layer, and once you've granted access the horses have fled the barn. But an alternative (and I would say better) design is one in which the code comes to the data and runs in a sandbox from which it cannot exfiltrate data. #26 hints at this, though it's not made explicit.
cross-linking with issue #15 which has some commonality to this topic
cross-linking with issue #25 which has some commonality to this topic

I believe W3C's role may include developing guidelines on the conversational user interface in browsers, which still dominates the way people interact with AI LLMs today (and the inclusion of LLMs in search might reinforce this). These guidelines might address accessibility and internationalization aspects, but also issues related to provenance of the data and the underlying reasoning and, possibly, aspects of both security and privacy.  (Many of these issues are already mentioned in other "advisement" sections.) Issues on ergonomy, on user interface, etc, should also get a special attention.

W3C has experience, largely, though not exclusively, due to the WAI activity, on creating such guidelines, how to manage them, present them, etc. This may become extremely useful.

(This is clearly related to #25.)

There is also the case to be made for different accessibility needs as well; speech to text transcription is already deployed in the wild which provides text descriptions for audio content. Cognitive accessibility needs could also be served through text models (e.g. please rephrase this in simple english, please summarize for two simple examples).

While both have limits on the guarantees in terms of bias and accuracy, there is definite promise for incremental progress for both cases.
for future reference (including my own since I haven't read it through yet) https://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/w3c-wai-gl/2024AprJun/thread.html#msg5

Left unchecked, search engines could evolve to progressively encroach on the value provided by individual websites, with the risk of monopolistic control and stifling of innovation.  Open standards are needed to enable open and free competition for personal assistants based upon generative AI.  Such assistants would build upon an open ecosystem of services with heterogeneous business models and machine interpretable descriptions that facilitate service composition. In principle, W3C could play a strategic role for community building and standards development.  We would need to identify which national and international bodies would have a shared interest in encouraging this further. A co-organized workshop would seem a good stepping stone.

> On 16 May 2024, at 19:58, Ivan Herman ***@***.***> wrote:
> 
> 
> A recent article on Google I/O <https://www.platformer.news/google-io-ai-search-sundar-pichai/> describes a vision for the evolution of search. "Let Google do the Googling for you" is the slogan used in the keynote of S. Pichai. It is not only Google; Bing, perplexity.ai, you.com, the Arc browser, maybe Siri tomorrow all use the same approach.
> 
> I quote the last paragraph of the paper:
> 
> […] to everyone who depended even a little bit on web search to have their business discovered, or their blog post read, or their journalism funded, the arrival of AI search bodes ill for the future. Google will now do the Googling for you, and everyone who benefited from humans doing the Googling will very soon need to come up with a Plan B.
> 
> This strikes me as potentially having an effect on W3C's activity in this area <https://www.w3.org/ecosystems/advertising/>, too: it may indeed become a paradigm shift, affecting business models that make the Web function today.
> 
> Would it be worth mentioning this in the document?

To "reinforce or reinstate the web's status as a public commons" would in my understanding also mean initiating recommendations for the access of non-public data securely, using, for instance, techniques like [Federated Learning](https://ai.googleblog.com/2017/04/federated-learning-collaborative.html), [Differential Privacy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Differential_privacy), and [Encrypted Computation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homomorphic_encryption).
There are as well solutions emerging in the open source community for this reason, e.g. [OpenMined](https://openmined.org).

also relevant:
* https://github.com/wiCG/handwriting-recognition Handwriting recognition
* https://developer.chrome.com/docs/ai/built-in?hl=en LLM prompt API (and similar proposal discussed in a lightning talk at W3C AC Meeting 2024 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7S60LNBAFj0 )
